Please be advised that testimonials will be shared with sponsors and may be used for promotional materials, website content, and future event marketing to highlight attendee experiences and feedback.

column56: Q. Data CollectionAny data/information collected (from you) will be used for the purpose of administration by the NHS-R Community, The Strategy Unit, NHS Python Community and event co-sponsors and will not be disclosed to any third party, except within the terms of the UK Data Protection Act 2018. In addition, the data/information submitted via this survey will be used to support the NHS-R Community's, The Strategy Unit's, NHS Python Community's and event co-sponsors' event management, marketing and market research activities.

column50: Attending RPysOC 2025 virtually  was an outstanding experience. The event brought together an inspiring community of professionals who were genuinely willing to share knowledge, support each other, and collaborate. The sessions were engaging, the content was practical and relevant, and the speakers created a welcoming environment that encouraged participation and learning. I left feeling motivated, better connected, and more confident in applying new skills and ideas to my work. I would highly recommend RPysOC to anyone looking to expand their expertise and be part of a supportive professional network.

column41: It's fine for me but I wonder about others who have good questions but aren't really Slack users so can't be bothered to use it or the entry barrier of signing up etc is too high for it to be worth it for them. The advantages are that it is a much better use of time than having questions from the floor in real time and it brings the online and in-person audiences together on a level playing field and promotes interaction. Also provides a rcord of sorts of what was asked (though of course Slack only has a memory of 90 days).
column43: Didn't attend but I think it is a great idea and an invaluable part of the event, making it the kind of event that it is. I'm really grateful to Pawel and Brittany for making it happen every year.

column50:
Please feel free to use any comments I've already made above.
The keynotes were excellent, especially Cara and Ben.
The venue was lovely and the food, and it was really easy to get to from the Tube. In some ways Birmingham is cheaper easier and more central but it did fell really exciting to be in London especially being near Oxford Street for the social, in the lead up to Christmas. I think tit would be great to be there agin next year if we can be. The AV worked really well, except for a couple of hitches which were probably more to do with the presenter's laptops than the venue?? Being back in Birmingham next year would also be great though.

In summary I'd say "The conference is enjoyable, relaxed and inspiring, and it's such an important point in the year to gather as a professional community and find out what everyone has been up to!"

column50:
The content of the talks and breakouts at RPySOC 2025 were inspiring and practical in equal measure. It's very rare, and therefore precious, to have the opportunity to learn deep technical detail from highly knowledgable people with experience of getting things done with data in the NHS. 

Everyone is friendly, easy to talk to and open to ideas, which makes for very enjoyable and energising conversations. In years of conference-going, I have rarely found one where ideas and knowledge flow so freely as they do within the NHS Open Analytics community. 

As the content directly addresses challenges that data scientists tackle every day in the NHS, it is highly relevant and valuable to everyday work that I and others are doing. 

This combination - inspiring, practical content, enjoyable and easy conversation, and laser focus on the specifics of the NHS - is unique.

column50:
This conference was a highlight for me this year. Here's what I shared on my way home:

On a delayed train back to Edinburgh after the NHS-OA conference. Worth the trek down to London and back? Absolutely!

Here are some highlights that are only possible because it was in person:

 Informal chats with folks over coffees and lunches, being able to help each other out and overhearing those "can I try it out in my trust and maybe that will help us build something more generalisable to others?" conversations

?? Those "how was your dinner with your friends?" / "did you manage to resolve that tricky situation?" moments of human connection that are so much harder to do online

 The Unconference sessions where we explored ideas that just came out of all those conversations

This conference is so important, creating community for analysts who are essentially all on the same team but scattered around the country. And I think we all left with plenty of things to look up and apply in our own contexts!

Keep up the good work - it's pretty amazing

column35: Ben Goldacre's talk was really great and also enjoyed the last one on LLMs. The talks on unit testing and kubernetes were very helpful for something I knew little of
column41: I hate slack i am already signed up to several channels and it becomes a huge pain to manage the volume of messaging - our work doesn't support it on device so I'm left refreshing a half dozen webpages that have dozens of conversation threads - its info overload - the point of being in person is that we actually can talk to each other there in person! I do not like at all the comments/questions are just pushed online to a location many people will ignore. Please please open up time for questions. Of course you can ask them after the talks but its a disservice to the community as it is no longer a public conversation. Despite my dislike of slack it does have its place of course as a community forum but I don't like it being the only question area.
column43: Whoile the organisers are clearly enthusiastic but i feel like the improvisational nature of it means there's not much info to go on to choose between watching a scheduled talk vs checking out a session. I think it would be better served to have people propose ideas a couple weeks ahead with a bit of a mission statement and have it publicly shared alongside the program - I realise that goes against the nature of this but its hard to justify skipping a prepared talk to go to an unconference session that might have 1-2 people sitting in for an unstructured conversation - it could be valuable but also may not
column47: Some really good talks esp Goldacre, Amadeus from Newtonstree, and several others
column48: Please have in person questions. Please post the abstracts. I feel like there were too many lightning talks and could be more diverse (there were 3 talks all on different capacity models) If you allow in person questions you could cut a few of the lightning. Maybe have a round table discussion? Also the plans for the 1st night should be public - our group had no idea so couldn't make it as we'd already booked ourselves elsewhere

column43: I find the unconferencing sessions to be such a great addition to the conference experience. Having a community-led stream like this with opportunities for deeper chats with people who have a shared interest in a particular problem feels like it provides a great opportunity for helping ideas and solutions to germinate. It makes a big difference to have this running near to the main event - I didn't attend any in 2023 due to the challenges of getting to the sessions, but in 2024 and this year, I attended a large number of sessions and really valued the insights of the other participants.
column47: How practical the things talked about are
column48: I found the sign-up process a little confusing this year. It was only several weeks later that I realised there were additional tasks to do to finalise my registration and the days I planned to attend, and then I was a bit unsure whether I'd registered successfully.
column50:
This conference is the most consistently useful one I've attended. Year after year, I come away with a long list of useful things to try out. 

If this event were to move to virtual only, it would be a huge loss to the open analytics community. Writing code in the NHS is often quite an isolated experience, with many people being the only person in their organisation, or one of a handful, who are flying the flag for open analytics and better use of data. There is nothing else in the calendar that does such a good job of allowing analysts and others to share ideas, improve their practice, and grow their network.
column56: Yes, I agree to share my data.

column48: Maybe have a "speed dating" style introductory session at the start of the conference? I.e. a 1 minute chat with a partner, then switch partners. Just as a quick exercise to get people talking.
column50: Engaging with the NHS R community, particularly through the conference, has really inspired me to keep implementing R in my home department. The NHS R community is supportive, passionate and very welcoming to newcomers, which I've really benefited from. I've come away from the conference with tangible pieces of knowledge that I will now apply in my NHS role, and also a more general sense of optimism that many brilliant people are doing good data science with open-source tools to help NHS patients.

column50: It is refreshing and invigorating to spend a few days with likeminded people that want to move the needle on advanced analytics in the NHS and enable evidence based decision making. I am grateful for the opportunity to see the variety of work available to build on and the rare opportunity to speak to current (and future!) collaborators in person. The community has learnt together and every year it feels like there's a slightly more stretching goal to work towards which I have enjoyed.

column43: First time I participated in Unconferencing. Was incredibly useful to hear from colleagues across different organisations on different topics. I stayed in more sessions than I intended to because the transitions were incredibly quick and I felt a bit awkward leaving when the next topic organiser dropped in. However, I do appreciate this is in the nature and colleagues running sessions would likely not mind people hopping up and leaving as they settle in. Really enjoyed all the sessions though and happy I did stay. Food for thought, maybe give a 30 second window for people to drop in and out before topic conversations transition.
